Workflow and user interface design review


2006-01-12 (Thu.) 7:00 PM – 9:00 PM

Attendees: Mr. Ko (BJ), Ms. Lee(SS) , Mr. Heo (HO) , Mr. Park (KJ), Mr. Boo (KH)

Agenda:
•        Workflow review
•        User interface review
•        Database change
•        Tasks assignment

Workflow review




  • HO started with the business scenario (http://studygroup.wikispaces.com/srs.html#toc13).


  • HO presented the storyboard (http://studygroup.wikispaces.com/sdd.html).


User Interface review


Screen 12

KJ: Should we allow a user to delete the courses from 12?
(Note that the numbers represent relevant screenshots in the storyboard)
HO: There may be a case where a user adds a course by mistake and it would be OK to delete the course as long as the course has not been referenced anywhere yet.
KH: The system will have to popup a deletion confirmation message before deleting a course.

Screen 16

KH: From 16, it would be better to display the list of available course types in a dropdown list (as opposed to current radio buttons). This is because new course types would have to be added in the future.
KJ: Agreed

Screen 25

KJ: From 25, course deletion should be done selectively.

Screen 2

KB: From 2, we need to use first and last name (as opposed to name) for student search.
KJ: For the search result fields, I’d like to see student number, first name, last name, and a telephone number.
KB: The search type does not need to include 'all' so that a student search can be done throughout the entire search category?
KJ: We don’t need it.

Screen 3

KJ: In 3, two addresses need to be shown. Add a radio button in between to indicate whether or not the two addresses are identical. If so, the system will copy the values of the first address to the second one.
KJ: Let’s change the date of birth (DOB) format to mm/dd/yyyy.
KJ: Change the Reference section to use a free format textbox (from the current radio buttons)

Screen 6

KJ: In 6, is a user allowed to delete the course information items and why?
KJ: Remove the dropdown list of courses and add a term column in the course information instead.
HO: What is a maximum number of terms a student would attend?
KJ: About 15 terms, and 50 courses
HO: Need to add an edit button in 6.
BJ: Remove the delete button from 6 and add an edit button for updating the courses or adding a new course,


Screen 7

KJ: In 7, use the term ‘Register’ rather than ‘Taken’ for the checkboxes.

Screen 15

In 15, the course types should be listed in a dropdown list.

Screen 23

KJ: In 23, make it to list the course history only. Add a dropdown list to list available terms.
BJ: I will code encryption/decryption functions for user password.

Screen 32

KH: Users will be authorized based on their roles assigned. There will be 4 levels of privileges initially.
BJ: I don’t see a difference from the current checkbox (task) based authorization.
SS: An advantage of the role based authorization is that the UI screens are pre-determined as soon as a user logs in to the system. The functions a user does not need may be grayed out or not displayed at all.
KH: By using task based authorization, there would be a maintenance problem because the list of tasks are likely to change continuously in the future even not frequently.
KH: Let’s use only one role – i.e. supervisor – for the initial development phase.
SS: This will be omitted from the UI testing item as well then.
KH: Agreed.

Database change


KJ: I have a second thought that I need to keep detailed info for instructors - last name, first name, address, two phone numbers, SIN, email, hired date, and additional notes.
KJ: I need a teaching history of the instructors provided by the system.

Tasks assignment


HO: JSPs and Struts configuration
KH: Database, model, and Hibernate mapping
SS: Ruby/Watir
BJ: JUnit for persistence testing
